";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:22:"useful-resources-links";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"transcript";s:0:"";s:15:"is_downloadable";b:1;s:7:"is_free";b:0;s:5:"asset";a:5:{s:6:"_class";s:5:"asset";s:2:"id";i:9964420;s:10:"asset_type";s:7:"Article";s:5:"title";s:0:"";s:7:"created";s:20:"2017-10-19T14:58:01Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:376;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:0;}i:86;a:7:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"chapter";s:2:"id";i:1964604;s:7:"created";s:20:"2017-09-28T11:13:33Z";s:10:"sort_order";i:375;s:5:"title";s:47:"Diving Deeper into Components & React Internals";s:11:"description";s:116:"Students will understand the internals of React, advanced features and also know how to use these advanced concepts.";s:12:"is_published";b:1;}i:87;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:8103724;s:5:"title";s:19:"Module Introduction";s:7:"created";s:20:"2017-09-28T11:13:39Z";s:11:"description";s:83:"

Let me introduce you to this module and to what you're going to learn in it.

";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:19:"module-introduction";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"transcript";s:0:"";s:15:"is_downloadable";b:1;s:7:"is_free";b:0;s:5:"asset";a:5:{s:6:"_class";s:5:"asset";s:2:"id";i:9763040;s:10:"asset_type";s:5:"Video";s:5:"title";s:39:"component-deep-dive-01-introduction.mp4";s:7:"created";s:20:"2017-10-01T12:27:03Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:374;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:0;}i:88;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:8103728;s:5:"title";s:26:"A Better Project Structure";s:7:"created";s:20:"2017-09-28T11:13:51Z";s:11:"description";s:113:"

Thus far, we haven't spent that much time on the project structure. Let's change that now and optimize it.

";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:26:"a-better-project-structure";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"transcript";s:0:"";s:15:"is_downloadable";b:1;s:7:"is_free";b:0;s:5:"asset";a:5:{s:6:"_class";s:5:"asset";s:2:"id";i:9762976;s:10:"asset_type";s:5:"Video";s:5:"title";s:53:"component-deep-dive-02-a-better-project-structure.mp4";s:7:"created";s:20:"2017-10-01T12:27:03Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:373;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:0;}i:89;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:8103732;s:5:"title";s:32:"Splitting an App Into Components";s:7:"created";s:20:"2017-09-28T11:13:58Z";s:11:"description";s:109:"

Splitting an app into components is what React is all about. Learn how to split it up in this lecture.

";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:32:"splitting-an-app-into-components";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"transcript";s:0:"";s:15:"is_downloadable";b:1;s:7:"is_free";b:0;s:5:"asset";a:5:{s:6:"_class";s:5:"asset";s:2:"id";i:9762902;s:10:"asset_type";s:5:"Video";s:5:"title";s:59:"component-deep-dive-03-splitting-an-app-into-components.mp4";s:7:"created";s:20:"2017-10-01T12:27:03Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:372;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:0;}i:90;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:8103734;s:5:"title";s:43:"Comparing Stateless and Stateful Components";s:7:"created";s:20:"2017-09-28T11:14:15Z";s:11:"description";s:114:"

As you learned, you have two different options for creating React components. Time for another closer look.

";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:43:"comparing-stateless-and-stateful-components";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"transcript";s:0:"";s:15:"is_downloadable";b:1;s:7:"is_free";b:0;s:5:"asset";a:5:{s:6:"_class";s:5:"asset";s:2:"id";i:9763088;s:10:"asset_type";s:5:"Video";s:5:"title";s:59:"component-deep-dive-04-stateless-vs-stateful-components.mp4";s:7:"created";s:20:"2017-10-01T12:27:04Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:371;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:0;}i:91;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:8103740;s:5:"title";s:37:"Understanding the Component Lifecycle";s:7:"created";s:20:"2017-09-28T11:14:26Z";s:11:"description";s:166:"

React components follow a certain lifecycle - and you can hook into that lifecycle at clearly defined points. Let's explore our options and how that all works.

";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:37:"understanding-the-component-lifecycle";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"transcript";s:0:"";s:15:"is_downloadable";b:1;s:7:"is_free";b:0;s:5:"asset";a:5:{s:6:"_class";s:5:"asset";s:2:"id";i:9762996;s:10:"asset_type";s:5:"Video";s:5:"title";s:64:"component-deep-dive-05-understanding-the-component-lifecycle.mp4";s:7:"created";s:20:"2017-10-01T12:27:03Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:370;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:0;}i:92;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:8103742;s:5:"title";s:43:"Converting Stateless to Stateful Components";s:7:"created";s:20:"2017-09-28T11:14:37Z";s:11:"description";s:122:"

Sometimes, you need to convert stateless components to stateful components. Learn how easy that is in this lecture.

";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:43:"converting-stateless-to-stateful-components";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"transcript";s:0:"";s:15:"is_downloadable";b:1;s:7:"is_free";b:0;s:5:"asset";a:5:{s:6:"_class";s:5:"asset";s:2:"id";i:9763076;s:10:"asset_type";s:5:"Video";s:5:"title";s:69:"component-deep-dive-06-coverting-stateless-to-stateful-components.mp4";s:7:"created";s:20:"2017-10-01T12:27:04Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:369;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:0;}i:93;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:8103744;s:5:"title";s:38:"Component Creation Lifecycle in Action";s:7:"created";s:20:"2017-09-28T11:14:55Z";s:11:"description";s:117:"

Let's start with the Lifecycle that applies when a component is created and let's see all the hooks in action.

";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:38:"component-creation-lifecycle-in-action";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"transcript";s:0:"";s:15:"is_downloadable";b:1;s:7:"is_free";b:0;s:5:"asset";a:5:{s:6:"_class";s:5:"asset";s:2:"id";i:9763024;s:10:"asset_type";s:5:"Video";s:5:"title";s:65:"component-deep-dive-07-component-creation-lifecycle-in-action.mp4";s:7:"created";s:20:"2017-10-01T12:27:03Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:368;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:0;}i:94;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:8140299;s:5:"title";s:22:"componentWillUnmount()";s:7:"created";s:20:"2017-10-03T06:11:53Z";s:11:"description";s:117:"

There's one more lifecycle method you should be aware of - we'll also use it later in our course project.

";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:20:"componentwillunmount";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"transcript";s:0:"";s:15:"is_downloadable";b:1;s:7:"is_free";b:0;s:5:"asset";a:5:{s:6:"_class";s:5:"asset";s:2:"id";i:9781973;s:10:"asset_type";s:7:"Article";s:5:"title";s:0:"";s:7:"created";s:20:"2017-10-03T06:17:49Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:367;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:0;}i:95;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:8103746;s:5:"title";s:34:"Component Updating Lifecycle Hooks";s:7:"created";s:20:"2017-09-28T11:15:07Z";s:11:"description";s:123:"

We had a look at the lifecycle for component creation, let's now also explore the counterpart for component updates.

";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:34:"component-updating-lifecycle-hooks";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"transcript";s:0:"";s:15:"is_downloadable";b:1;s:7:"is_free";b:0;s:5:"asset";a:5:{s:6:"_class";s:5:"asset";s:2:"id";i:9763034;s:10:"asset_type";s:5:"Video";s:5:"title";s:55:"component-deep-dive-08-component-lifecycle-updating.mp4";s:7:"created";s:20:"2017-10-01T12:27:03Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:366;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:0;}i:96;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:8103748;s:5:"title";s:38:"Component Updating Lifecycle in Action";s:7:"created";s:20:"2017-09-28T11:15:20Z";s:11:"description";s:73:"

Time to also see the component-updating lifecycle hooks in action.

";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:38:"component-updating-lifecycle-in-action";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"transcript";s:0:"";s:15:"is_downloadable";b:1;s:7:"is_free";b:0;s:5:"asset";a:5:{s:6:"_class";s:5:"asset";s:2:"id";i:9762918;s:10:"asset_type";s:5:"Video";s:5:"title";s:60:"component-deep-dive-09-implementing-update-related-hooks.mp4";s:7:"created";s:20:"2017-10-01T12:27:03Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:365;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:0;}i:97;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:8103752;s:5:"title";s:53:"Updating Lifecycle Hooks (Triggered by State Changes)";s:7:"created";s:20:"2017-09-28T11:15:36Z";s:11:"description";s:123:"

Finally, we have two ways of updating components - the lifecycles also vary slightly. Time to find out what differs.

";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:51:"updating-lifecycle-hooks-triggered-by-state-changes";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"transcript";s:0:"";s:15:"is_downloadable";b:1;s:7:"is_free";b:0;s:5:"asset";a:5:{s:6:"_class";s:5:"asset";s:2:"id";i:9763020;s:10:"asset_type";s:5:"Video";s:5:"title";s:65:"component-deep-dive-10-lifecycle-updating-by-internal-changes.mp4";s:7:"created";s:20:"2017-10-01T12:27:03Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:364;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:0;}i:98;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:8103756;s:5:"title";s:37:"Performance Gains with PureComponents";s:7:"created";s:20:"2017-09-28T11:15:44Z";s:11:"description";s:162:"

shouldComponentUpdate is an important lifecycle method - we can have an easier time optimizing the component performance though. Let's explore the options.

";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:37:"performance-gains-with-purecomponents";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"transcript";s:0:"";s:15:"is_downloadable";b:1;s:7:"is_free";b:0;s:5:"asset";a:5:{s:6:"_class";s:5:"asset";s:2:"id";i:9763078;s:10:"asset_type";s:5:"Video";s:5:"title";s:64:"component-deep-dive-11-performance-gains-with-purecomponents.mp4";s:7:"created";s:20:"2017-10-01T12:27:04Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:363;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:0;}i:99;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:8103760;s:5:"title";s:42:"How React Updates the App & Component Tree";s:7:"created";s:20:"2017-09-28T11:15:54Z";s:11:"description";s:145:"

We're already taking a closer look under the React hood. Let's continue this road and find out how it actually updates the component tree.

";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:40:"how-react-updates-the-app-component-tree";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"transcript";s:0:"";s:15:"is_downloadable";b:1;s:7:"is_free";b:0;s:5:"asset";a:5:{s:6:"_class";s:5:"asset";s:2:"id";i:9762896;s:10:"asset_type";s:5:"Video";s:5:"title";s:64:"component-deep-dive-12-how-react-renders-and-updates-the-app.mp4";s:7:"created";s:20:"2017-10-01T12:27:03Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:362;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:0;}}}

item.title: JavaScript latest 2018 course - JavaScript for beginners
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
What is javascript?

javascriptis a programming language that is usually used for web pages and applications. Its primary purpose on the Web is to add more functionality to pages. Good examples of javascript applications are online quizzes and surveys.

javascript is a high-level, dynamic, run-time language.

Why JavaScript is important?

If you want to learn web designing, or web developing javascript is one of the fundamental things you should know and master.

javascript is a client-side programming/scripting language most of the time we are using javascript for static web pages to make it dynamic.

There are many reason you should learn javascript like it is a good introduction to computer programming.

The Advantages of javascript

javascript has multiple libraries and frameworks you can take advantage of. Just being familiar with javascript will be good enough for you to use and embed awesome functions in your applets or pages. Why? Because you can take advantage of its multiple frameworks and libraries that will make your life easier. Aside from that, it executes fast.

Why you should take this course?

This course is created for those who want to learn javascript from a-z if you are totally new in JavaScript this course will guide you to learn JavaScript than if you know some basic about javascript again this course will take your carrier to the next advance level of javascript I have explained the lectures that anyone can understand.

Project inside this course.

You will learn how to use JavaScript to build

1. javascript Birth Finder

2. javascript Simple Calculator

3. javascript Image Slider

item.title: Creating Responsive Web Design
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Learn how to create websites that adjust to any screen size while optimizing download speeds.

  • HTML5, CSS3, and Media Queries
  • HTML5Shiv for Internet Explorer
  • Photoshop Image Optimization and Slicing
  • Design Adaptations for Various Screens

Create Websites that are Optimized for All Screens
Because people use a variety of devices to access the Internet, it's important that, as a website designer, you know how to create a site that will conform to any screen size. Today's websites should be able to resize and rearrange elements and content automatically so that any user on any device from anywhere in the world can access your site and browse it with ease. And building a website that's compatible with the many browsers available from both the past and the present is also an integral part of launching a strong site.

Not every website designer knows how to create these "intelligent" websites. With the right training, you can differentiate yourself from the competition and potentially expand your client base.

Contents and Overview
In just 1.5 hours and through 11 lectures, you'll learn all that you need to know to create a dazzling website using CSS3 and HTML5. You'll understand how to make your site backwards compatible with old browsers, and how to set it up using CSS rules so that it will adjust itself to any screen size while optimizing download speeds. This course, which is ideal for web developers, graphic designers, usability experts, and interaction designers, will even provide you with CSS, HTML, and Photoshop templates that you can use to design your own sites.

Upon successful completion of this course, you'll be confident in your abilities to design a customized website that's optimized to work on any computer or mobile device. From the creation of CSS files to the design of a site's layout, text, and graphics, you'll be fully versed in launching a site that's going to appear just as you intended, regardless of what screen your visitors will be using.

This introducion shows this web design final project adapting to various browsers, platforms, and screen sizes.

";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:12:"introduction";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"transcript";s:4691:"Hi. This is Chris Converse of Codified Design Studio. And this is a course I've put together in creating multi-screen web design. So what I want to do in this introduction is show you the final project that we're going to be creating. So I'm going to open this HTML file up in a browser. So what we're doing here is using HTML 5 and CSS3 Media Queries to create a design that can change or manipulate itself based on the view port of the browser browsing your website. So what I'm going to do here is take this web window and open it up. And when we get higher than 980 pixels, the design's going to lock itself down and then center in the browser. When I get below 980 pixels, we're going to set the design up to be liquid or fluid so that all of the items in the page will actually stretch to conform to the overall width of the browser. When I come under a certain pixel width, in this case 500 pixels, notice that the design and the banner changed from a larger banner, and a larger logo, and a larger sidebar photo to a much smaller banner size, much smaller buttons, more spaced-out. The assumption here is that we're probably on a tablet device because we're under 800 pixels on the horizontal. So I spaced out the buttons to make sure you can tap them with your fingers. And then when we get even smaller, under 500 pixels, we rearrange the content altogether. We take the sidebar and move it under the content. And we even take those links at the top and move them down to be underneath the content. So if somebody visits this same page on a mobile device, they can flick their finger down to the bottom and then use the navigation content links once they've finished reading the content. Now I did mention that we'll be using HTML 5. There are some older browsers that don't support HTML 5 and some CSS3 attributes. So what we're going to do in here is we're going to make use of a Google Shiv, that's an HTML 5 Java Script enabler for IE7 and 8. So here we are inside of IE7 which is using semi-transparency based on an alternate style sheet. And it's even rendering the heading area which is an HTML 5 tag, a footer area which is an HTML 5 tag, and a navigation item up here which is also HTML 5. So while IE7 does not support the device sensitive layout changing, we do see the layout working correctly in IE7. If we hop over to IE9 running in Windows 7, we can see the device is working over here as well. I can even close this down because IE9 has device sensitivity as well. So I can scroll down here and see the button showing up down at the bottom. But what makes this so powerful is that we can run the same content in devices as well. So here's the same design running on an iPad in the simulator here. And if I rotate the screen, I can see that the device will actually change. In this case, we see this medium screen display versus the large screen display. One thing you might notice on iOS devices, the phone and iPad, we might have to pinch down to change, but here we're seeing that full computer screen size. In addition, let's hop over to Android. So inside the Android environment, we can see Android on a horizontal. It's showing me the tablet view. And I'll hit Ctrl-F11 in the simulator here, and take a look at the Android rendering this page with the width similar to the phone views. Now I can tap and scroll down here, and see the button showing up at the bottom as we would see it on a mobile Android phone. So during this course, we're going to be creating the HTML and CSS files necessary to make all of these layouts happen across all of these different screen sizes. And so one of the things we're going to do is be referring back to a sketch. So I always prefer creating a sketch of your interactive projects. This gives us the ability to figure out some of the measurements, figure out our strategy as far as HTML and CSS is concerned, and give us an idea of when we're in the HTML and CSS of what some of the measurements are going to be. So in this sketch here, we've actually defined out how we're going to have the design changing. So we've seen this working in all the different browsers. And this is the sketch we came up with to sort of figure out what's going to happen. Figure out the fact that the navigation is actually going to move from the top area on both the computer and table area to moving down to being under the content on the mobile phone area. We're also taking these content areas, the left side and right side content container, and shifting them to be vertical when we switch over to the handheld device as well. So I hope this course sounds interesting to you. And if it does, let's get started with the first movie.";s:15:"is_downloadable";b:1;s:7:"is_free";b:1;s:5:"asset";a:5:{s:6:"_class";s:5:"asset";s:2:"id";i:37509;s:10:"asset_type";s:5:"Video";s:5:"title";s:12:"Introduction";s:7:"created";s:20:"2011-08-01T21:29:06Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:14;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:1;}i:27;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:44394;s:5:"title";s:24:"Review the Project Files";s:7:"created";s:20:"2011-08-01T21:32:04Z";s:11:"description";s:66:"

A quick walkthrough of the files provided with this course.

item.title: Responsive Design HTML CSS Web design - Dreamweaver CC
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Hi there, my name is Dan and together were going to build a portfolio website using Adobe Dreamweaver.

Well use Dreamweaver's handy templating tools to make updates to our site super easy. Well create our very own mobile 'burger menu' from scratch learning some basic JavaScript & jQuery.

I am an Adobe Certified Instructor and better yet I work closely with Adobe themselves to develop their own online help videos. I am also a Dreamweaver speaker at the huge Adobe Max conference in Las Vegas. Im even inside your version of Dreamweaver right now... go on try it... open Dreamweaver> Go to Help > quick tutorial - Im right there!

This course is for beginners. You do not need any previous knowledge in Dreamweaver or web design. We will use Dreamweaver split view so we can use all the good visual tools as well as doing some simple amends down here in the code as well.

In this series we will take this static design from either Illustrator or Photoshop and together, step by step, build everything in HTML5, CSS3 & JavaScript. We will make our own responsive design navigation. We will make adjustments so that everything looks great on different mobile devices.

We will work with beautiful fonts & colours & even add Google Analytics to our site to get amazing information about exactly who visits your site. Now web design can sometimes be tricky so I am here to help - just message me if you get stuck. There are also exercise files so you can follow along. I even save a full copy of the website at the end of every video so that you can check yours again mine if youre is not working quite right.

Let's get excited about finally being able to build a website like a professional web designer. See you in class.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Learn HTML5 & CSS3 web design skills. Build beautiful responsive design websites in Dreamweaver CC

a:3:{i:0;s:102:"You will need a copy of Adobe Dreamweaver CC 2017 or above. A free trial can be downloaded from Adobe.";i:1;s:41:"No previous web design skills are needed.";i:2;s:42:"No previous Dreamweaver skills are needed.";}

In this video we're going to sign up for Google Analytics. Why? Because it gives you all of this information about who comes to your site, it's free, you can see, in my case, how many people have paid for courses on bringyourownlaptop.com in the last seven days, how many people are currently on the site, six of you, what times of the day they are, what countries they're from, all sorts of goodness. 

";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:55:"how-to-add-google-analytics-to-your-dreamweaver-website";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"transcript";s:0:"";s:15:"is_downloadable";b:0;s:7:"is_free";b:0;s:5:"asset";a:5:{s:6:"_class";s:5:"asset";s:2:"id";i:9550072;s:10:"asset_type";s:5:"Video";s:5:"title";s:65:"36 How to adding Google Analytics to your Dreamweaver website.mp4";s:7:"created";s:20:"2017-09-11T03:57:40Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:3;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:0;}i:47;a:7:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"chapter";s:2:"id";i:1929618;s:7:"created";s:20:"2017-09-07T22:19:10Z";s:10:"sort_order";i:2;s:5:"title";s:9:"What Next";s:11:"description";s:0:"";s:12:"is_published";b:1;}i:48;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:7937764;s:5:"title";s:35:"What next in the Dreamweaver course";s:7:"created";s:20:"2017-09-07T22:19:14Z";s:11:"description";s:451:"

Okay, so what to do next? You've built the site in Dreamweaver, so we've got a working website but you might not have done the design side, you might have skipped that, and just worked from my Illustrator file. So, Illustrator was done in a separate course, check out the link here. That's where we picked the colors, the images, and the fonts, and all those types of things. And then we built them in this course in Dreamweaver, so go do that.

";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:35:"what-next-in-the-dreamweaver-course";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"transcript";s:0:"";s:15:"is_downloadable";b:0;s:7:"is_free";b:0;s:5:"asset";a:5:{s:6:"_class";s:5:"asset";s:2:"id";i:9550138;s:10:"asset_type";s:5:"Video";s:5:"title";s:19:"37 What next B2.mp4";s:7:"created";s:20:"2017-09-11T04:09:17Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:1;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:0;}i:49;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:7937766;s:5:"title";s:26:"Dreamweaver class exercise";s:7:"created";s:20:"2017-09-07T22:19:17Z";s:11:"description";s:360:"

All right, it is Class Exercise time. So, there are two options. The first one is to continue on with this course and build us a Contact Us and About Us page. So, put content in there, link it to the Home page, and then either upload it to our host, so I can see it, or test it locally and send me a screenshot. I'd like to see what you've done with it.

item.title: Ultimate Guide to Digital Sketching: Beginner to Advanced
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Join the course and begin drawingtoday!

Do you want to learn how todigitally sketchimages for games and film like an industry pro? Or maybe youre wanting to branch out and try working digitally? In any case youve come to the right place.

The 'The Ultimate Guide to Digital Sketching: Beginner to Advanced' coursewill show you how to digitally sketch and draw skilled imagesthat will stand up as professional work. The techniques taught in this course can be translated into any program from Photoshop to Procreate.This course will enhance or give you skills in digital drawing,or your money back!

Thiscourse is your track to building a solid portfolio of digital artandconcept art! Whether for your own portfolioor for client work.

This course will take you from having little knowledge in how to drawand sketchto creating professional drawingsin as little as one week.

So what else is in it for you?

Youll be taken from basic sketches to creative ideas and drawings, from beginner to expert

Youll gain instant access to allof the course.You can follow along and recreate my drawingsor use it as inspiration to drawyour own masterpiece.

The course is setup to quickly take you through step by step, the process of creating digital sketches. It will equip you with the knowledge to create stunning images and concept art!

This all comes under one convenient easy to use platform. Plus you will get fast, friendly, responsive support on the Udemy Q&A section of the course or direct message.

I will be here for youevery step of the way!

So what are you waiting for? Sign up now tostart creating today!

[{"question":"How long do I have access to the course materials?","answer":"You can view and review the lecture materials indefinitely, like an on-demand channel."},{"question":"Can I take my courses with me wherever I go?","answer":"Definitely! If you have an internet connection, courses on Udemy are available on any device at any time. If you don't have an internet connection, some instructors also let their students download course lectures. That's up to the instructor though, so make sure you get on their good side!"}]

item.title: Adobe Illustrator for Mobile Game Art - A Beginners Guide
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
UPDATE [3/1/2015]:

1200+ STUDENTS UPON INITIAL COURSE LAUNCH! JOIN THIS GROWING COMMUNITY OF ASPIRING MOBILE GAME ARTIST AND START CREATING YOUR OWN MOBILE GAME ART! SHARE PROGRESS AND JOIN IN ON THE DISCUSSIONS.

*NEW SECTIONS ADDED - MATERIAL DESIGN SECTION

*NEW LECTURES ADDED - SMOOTH TOOL LECTURE

_____________________________________________________________________

"I really enjoyed going through this course. Rafael doesnt just teach you how to use some important tools in Adobe Illustrator, but he also teaches you the right techniques to use these tools to create good looking graphics in an easy way..."

-Eli Solowej, Make Mobile Game Art Student

Making mobile game art is never hard. All you need is the right mentor who can cut through the clutter and show you the core concepts, essential tools and proven workflows you only need to learn in order for you to become a mobile games artist.

Have you ever wanted to create mobile game art?

Make vector game art for video games?

But you struggle or get overwhelmed because you think there's so much you need to learn?

Questions and doubts arise.

-What are the concepts you need to learn?

-What tools to use?

-What workflows actually work?

-Do I even have to know how to draw?

-You have an idea but you just can't seem to create it the way you want it? And mobile game art creation is a bit overwhelming to you?

It doesn't have to be this way. Learning illustrator and creating professional mobile game art is EASY!

There's just to much clutter being taught everywhere and it handicaps you to actually learn and create the artwork you want. If you want to make mobile game art, improve your workflows and implement best practices to your game art creation process, this course is for you.

No shortcuts, just pure real world workflows! You can actually have the result you want in the fastest time possible and still create professional mobile game art. I have designed the course to let you have first-hand experience and be more confident in using illustrator upfront and get up and running in the quickest time possible and start making your own mobile game art.

Just practical, proven workflows to a professional mobile game art, fast and top-quality art.

___________________________________________________________________________

Give yourself a fresh new perspective in using Adobe Illustrator and making mobile game art in this beginners course now.

Save yourself from the headaches, clutter and overwhelming number of illustrator tools by only learning the core concepts, essential tools, workflows and best practices.

Take action because the one that get's the first hand experience in anything are the one's that learn best.

All future lectures to this mastery course are free - if you bought the course at the initial price of 99$ - you don't have to pay anything to get the new lectures.

And of course, there's a 30 day no fluff no questions full money back guarantee!

This course is mainly Adobe Illustrator for Mobile Game Art, but you can still follow along and use other similar software that has similar tools.

About this course:

  • Full, free lifetime access
  • The course would be regularly updated and more lectures will be added.
  • The awesome Udemy 30 day money-back-guarantee.
  • Regular free resources to fast start your mobile game creation journey.
  • Challenging tasks that let you validate everything you will learn in this course.
  • Full support from the instructor

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Create mobile game art in Adobe illustrator just by using basic concepts, essential tools and proven workflows.

a:6:{i:0;s:66:"No Prior knowledge of Adobe Illustrator or any art concept needed!";i:1;s:97:"Adobe Illustrator CS4 and up! or other vector program which has similar tools that I will discuss";i:2;s:108:"Your dedicated time and 100% attention. You will be thought with the basics and pro tips at the same time. ";i:3;s:133:"Know at least basic commands in Illustrator or already knows how to navigate. If you are completely new to the software. Even Better!";i:4;s:135:"An open, inquiring mind-its best if you have illustrator open at the same time so you can follow along. Experience is your best Teacher";i:5;s:75:"Keep in mind that there are no shortcuts, only faster ways of doing things!";}

And Congratulations on taking action and enrolling in my class.
You are sure to get its full benefits as I will lay down real world concepts, workflows and best practices in detail here. For the entirety of the course I will go over the concepts and tool you only need to know and start creating your own game art.
I will teach you from theory to application, from planning to execution and create professional looking mobile game art. You can follow along as I implement the concepts and workflows, and I will provide actionable materials and resources which you can use to practice every skill I will teach.

After this lecture you will be able to:
-Understand what the course is about and what it is not

-Know how we will go over the course and what to expect

In this video we will learn how to create and set custom keyboard shortcuts for our workflow.

Ok so to start with the shortcuts I use.

Pre-built shortcuts (already set as default)
  • P - Pen Tool
  • D - set any shape to default white fill and black stroke
  • M -for drawing squares and rectangles
  • L for drawing circles/ellipses
  • Shift +M - to access shape builder tool.
  • R to enter rotate mode and rotate my shapes

  • Ctrl + 7 - for masking shapes

  • Ctrl + D - to duplicate any action.

Custom Shortcuts

  • Shift + S - for screen blending mode
  • Shift + D - for multiply blending mode.
  • Ctrl + R for if I want to reflect or flip some shapes.
  • U for rounded rectangle
  • Keys 1~10 to give set my layer transparency in increments of 10.
  • So in my setup its 1 for 100%, 2 for 20%, 3 for 30 % and so on.
  • Ctrl + 2 to lock any shape.
  • Ctrl + Alt + 2 to unlock any shape
  • Ctrl + 3 to hide any shape from the artboard,
  • Ctrl + Alt + 3 to unhide shapes.

art brush.mp4";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-02-10T07:41:55Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:29;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:0;}i:24;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:2510630;s:5:"title";s:78:"Smooth Tool - Quick fix for your jagged curves + Pen Tool Review [New Lecture]";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-03-02T06:43:25Z";s:11:"description";s:931:"

In this new lecture I will be discussing the smooth too. This tool is really essential if you are doing "quick fix" on your shapes and you don't want to redraw them. I also included a review of the core tool "pen tool" so that we can lessen the instances where we need to fix our shape and save more time in the process.

After this video you will learn how to use and when to use the smooth tool. And a review of the pen tool and the mindset you need inorder to predetermine the placement of your anchor points. This is a response lecture to one student who had created his own game art but struggled a bit on the curves part (which is ok for anyone starting out. Again I am here to help everyone, and feel free to post your questions in the discussion boards. And I will do my best to answer it fast or even make a brand new lecture. Just like this one :)

Its all about the details indeed and in this video we are gonna discuss how to do just that.
In this video we will be reapplying our knowledge of creating art brush to make the detail scratches for the Barbarian Axe.

Also please note that some type of game themes do not require much details and its your call to make the game art more cartoony(less detail) or more realistic (more details) and each style will be perfect for the theme that requires it.

In this video we will finalize our game art and add chipped/dents to the blade and handle, overall border and shadow.
This are essential techniques which you need to learn and you can apply them to any of your next game art.

You will learn how to use masking to make worn out effects, use the offset feature in illustrator and add shadows the quick and easy way to your game art/prop

In this material design study we will go in detail how to easily create gold coins by just using simple shapes, a bit of shape builder tool blending modes. I'll also show how easy it is to create a variety of color scheme from just one artwork. You just need to keep in mind the tips I will discuss in this lecture.

After the lecture, you will discover more ways to make artwork faster, confidently create different versions from it by just tweaking its color and have a keen eye for detail

After this lecture you will be able to create your own metal materials in 2d style. And render metal properly.

Creative challenges ahead!";s:12:"is_published";b:1;}i:47;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:2321616;s:5:"title";s:44:"Your final Exam - Your own original game art";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-01-29T11:27:21Z";s:11:"description";s:483:"

Now that you have learned how to use adobe illustrator for game art, we will now put everything to that test.
You will now make and submit your first mobile game art. I am confident in your skills especially if you have gone this far. And I know you can now create one your self from scratch! And do not worry, just post any problems you might face in the discussion board, ill be hanging in there like a monkey waiting for your questions. - Rafael

";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:42:"your-final-exam-your-own-original-game-art";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"transcript";N;s:15:"is_downloadable";b:0;s:7:"is_free";b:0;s:5:"asset";a:5:{s:6:"_class";s:5:"asset";s:2:"id";i:2759176;s:10:"asset_type";s:7:"Article";s:5:"title";s:0:"";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-02-22T03:34:28Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:5;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:0;}i:48;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:4194154;s:5:"title";s:66:"A SPECIAL Bonus for YOU my game art student. Check the BONUS here!";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-12-19T01:54:05Z";s:11:"description";s:186:"

Thank you for taking my course on Making Mobile Game art. And as a special exclusive bonus for you,
You can get access to one of my top ranking Game Character Creation Course!

";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:64:"a-special-bonus-for-you-my-game-art-student-check-the-bonus-here";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"transcript";s:0:"";s:15:"is_downloadable";b:1;s:7:"is_free";b:0;s:5:"asset";a:5:{s:6:"_class";s:5:"asset";s:2:"id";i:5996632;s:10:"asset_type";s:7:"Article";s:5:"title";s:0:"";s:7:"created";s:20:"2016-05-14T11:37:02Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:2;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:0;}i:49;a:7:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"chapter";s:2:"id";i:1190800;s:7:"created";s:20:"2016-03-05T01:18:16Z";s:10:"sort_order";i:1;s:5:"title";s:9:"Resources";s:11:"description";s:44:"Download relevant resources from the course.";s:12:"is_published";b:1;}i:50;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:4676752;s:5:"title";s:14:"Resource Files";s:7:"created";s:20:"2016-03-05T01:19:29Z";s:11:"description";s:0:"";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:14:"resource-files";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"transcript";s:0:"";s:15:"is_downloadable";b:1;s:7:"is_free";b:0;s:5:"asset";a:5:{s:6:"_class";s:5:"asset";s:2:"id";i:5440462;s:10:"asset_type";s:7:"Article";s:5:"title";s:0:"";s:7:"created";s:20:"2016-03-05T01:33:47Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:0;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:0;}}}

item.title: Pixel art for Video games
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Imagine how cool your game would look in pixel art! Stop imagining!

==== UPDATED 26th of December==== *NEW SECTION* - Color theory

This section was added by popular demand as something that was missing from the course.Thank you for you patience, I wanted to make sure everything was as good as Icould make it. Enjoy!

In this course I'll use my 10+ years of experience to teach you all you need to know to start making your own pixel art. You'll go from zero to full speed in no time with simple exercises that will teach you the foundations as well as advanced concepts that help give your pixel art creations that professional look.

Featuring over 6 hours of footage, you'll be able to follow step by step as I take you through the creation of some really cool pixel art!

You'll learn:

  • Configuring Photoshop to draw in pixel art
  • Drawing lines and smooth shapes, such as circles
  • Shading and texture
  • The use of outlines

And once you get these concepts settled, you'll learn:

  • Creating tiles and adding detail to tilled images
  • Creating sprites while using a tile grid
  • Creating tiles in the style of top-down RPG games
  • Creating characters in top-down perspective
  • Creating some medieval style hud elements
  • Working in isometric perspective

You'll also:

  • create a CHARACTER
  • and ANIMATE it within minutes!
  • Learn about color theory

As a bonus round you'll get a chance to create a unity project and actually see your character move and jump around on the screen just like if it was in your video-game

Take this course now and you will see your pixel art skill skyrocket!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The essential course for creating stunning pixel art graphics for video-games or stylish illustrations and designs

[{"question":"How long do I have access to the course materials?","answer":"You can view and review the lecture materials indefinitely, like an on-demand channel."},{"question":"Can I take my courses with me wherever I go?","answer":"Definitely! If you have an internet connection, courses on Udemy are available on any device at any time. If you don't have an internet connection, some instructors also let their students download course lectures. That's up to the instructor though, so make sure you get on their good side!"}]

a:4:{s:5:"count";i:114;s:4:"next";s:90:"https://www.udemy.com/api-2.0/courses/397936/public-curriculum-items/?page=2&page_size=100";s:8:"previous";N;s:7:"results";a:100:{i:0;a:7:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"chapter";s:2:"id";i:596378;s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-01-19T11:47:35Z";s:10:"sort_order";i:115;s:5:"title";s:12:"Introduction";s:11:"description";s:0:"";s:12:"is_published";b:1;}i:1;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:2260078;s:5:"title";s:18:"Introduction Video";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-01-19T11:47:35Z";s:11:"description";s:31:"

Welcome to my course!

";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:18:"introduction-video";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"transcript";N;s:15:"is_downloadable";b:0;s:7:"is_free";b:1;s:5:"asset";a:5:{s:6:"_class";s:5:"asset";s:2:"id";i:2677300;s:10:"asset_type";s:5:"Video";s:5:"title";s:16:"Introduction.mov";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-02-10T16:13:10Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:114;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:1;}i:2;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:2260080;s:5:"title";s:29:"Pixel art and its limitations";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-01-19T11:48:16Z";s:11:"description";s:147:"

What is pixel art? how is it different from the other digital arts? have a listen as I talk and put some examples on the screen!

";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:29:"pixel-art-and-its-limitations";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"transcript";N;s:15:"is_downloadable";b:0;s:7:"is_free";b:1;s:5:"asset";a:5:{s:6:"_class";s:5:"asset";s:2:"id";i:2678178;s:10:"asset_type";s:5:"Video";s:5:"title";s:15:"limitations.mov";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-02-10T18:04:10Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:113;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:1;}i:3;a:7:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"chapter";s:2:"id";i:596380;s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-01-19T11:48:25Z";s:10:"sort_order";i:112;s:5:"title";s:28:"Creating pixel art - Lineart";s:11:"description";s:84:"This section will provide a firm knowledge of the fundamentals of creating pixel art";s:12:"is_published";b:1;}i:4;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:2432996;s:5:"title";s:22:"Working with Photoshop";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-02-17T19:57:14Z";s:11:"description";s:336:"

---- DOWNLOAD THE RESOURCES FOR REFERENCE ----
before we can confortably work in photoshop, lets take some time to learn the basic tools and some tricks to feel more at ease with photoshop it self. You'll learn how to create, duplicate and move layers. And also how to copy parts of a layer onto a new one, or onto itself.

";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:22:"working-with-photoshop";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"transcript";N;s:15:"is_downloadable";b:0;s:7:"is_free";b:0;s:5:"asset";a:5:{s:6:"_class";s:5:"asset";s:2:"id";i:2725520;s:10:"asset_type";s:5:"Video";s:5:"title";s:16:"00.photoshop.avi";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-02-17T20:03:53Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:111;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:0;}i:5;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:2260084;s:5:"title";s:35:"Configuring the tools for pixel art";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-01-19T11:49:17Z";s:11:"description";s:221:"

Using Photoshop for pixel art is perfectly fine, but give that its a very complex software with loads of features, we want to make sure that our tools are set specifically to work with pixel level illustrations

";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:35:"configuring-the-tools-for-pixel-art";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"transcript";N;s:15:"is_downloadable";b:0;s:7:"is_free";b:0;s:5:"asset";a:5:{s:6:"_class";s:5:"asset";s:2:"id";i:2531432;s:10:"asset_type";s:5:"Video";s:5:"title";s:23:"01.ConfiguringTools.avi";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-01-19T12:17:58Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:110;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:0;}i:6;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:2260092;s:5:"title";s:14:"Creating lines";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-01-19T11:51:51Z";s:11:"description";s:224:"

Drawing a line isn't just a matter of creating pixels next to each other. there are optimal line directions and optimal placement of pixel, to suggest a specific shape. In pixel art, every single pixel counts.

";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:14:"creating-lines";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"transcript";N;s:15:"is_downloadable";b:0;s:7:"is_free";b:0;s:5:"asset";a:5:{s:6:"_class";s:5:"asset";s:2:"id";i:2531402;s:10:"asset_type";s:5:"Video";s:5:"title";s:19:"02.DrawingLines.avi";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-01-19T12:12:14Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:109;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:0;}i:7;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:2260094;s:5:"title";s:16:"Creating circles";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-01-19T11:52:03Z";s:11:"description";s:317:"

Since a circle is the smoothest shape you can draw, its also the most complicated one to replicate in pixel art, while still ensuring it doesn't look like something else. In this lecture, I'll guide you through the smallest sizes you can draw a circle in, and what are the best aproaches.

";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:16:"creating-circles";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"transcript";N;s:15:"is_downloadable";b:0;s:7:"is_free";b:1;s:5:"asset";a:5:{s:6:"_class";s:5:"asset";s:2:"id";i:2531412;s:10:"asset_type";s:5:"Video";s:5:"title";s:21:"03.DrawingCircles.avi";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-01-19T12:13:53Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:108;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:1;}i:8;a:14:{s:6:"_class";s:4:"quiz";s:2:"id";i:115694;s:5:"title";s:28:"Creating Pixel art - Lineart";s:4:"type";s:11:"simple-quiz";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-02-20T16:01:04Z";s:11:"description";s:0:"";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:0:"";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"sort_order";i:107;s:12:"object_index";i:1;s:8:"is_draft";b:0;s:7:"version";i:1;s:8:"duration";N;s:12:"pass_percent";N;}i:9;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:2260098;s:5:"title";s:36:"Drawing your first sprite - a Sword!";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-01-19T11:52:24Z";s:11:"description";s:197:"

With the fundamentals or line and shape drawing, its time to draw your first sprite: A Sword!
We will create a simple shape, and fill it in with simplistic and flat colors.

";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:33:"drawing-your-first-sprite-a-sword";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"transcript";N;s:15:"is_downloadable";b:0;s:7:"is_free";b:0;s:5:"asset";a:5:{s:6:"_class";s:5:"asset";s:2:"id";i:2531418;s:10:"asset_type";s:5:"Video";s:5:"title";s:18:"04.SwordSprite.avi";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-01-19T12:15:00Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:106;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:0;}i:10;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:2392510;s:5:"title";s:36:"Exercise - trace over a book drawing";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-02-10T17:25:44Z";s:11:"description";s:342:"

Use this photoshop file to practice tracing over a drawing. Use the layer above all the others, and with the pencil tool create a line as clean as you can, over what YOU think, are the most important features on the drawing.If you are not using photoshop, you can use the png version of the file that you can find in the resources.

";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:34:"exercise-trace-over-a-book-drawing";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"transcript";N;s:15:"is_downloadable";b:1;s:7:"is_free";b:0;s:5:"asset";a:5:{s:6:"_class";s:5:"asset";s:2:"id";i:2677896;s:10:"asset_type";s:4:"File";s:5:"title";s:8:"book.psd";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-02-10T17:27:03Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:105;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:0;}i:11;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:2385720;s:5:"title";s:20:"Conclusion section 2";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-02-09T19:22:32Z";s:11:"description";s:0:"";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:20:"conclusion-section-2";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"transcript";N;s:15:"is_downloadable";b:0;s:7:"is_free";b:0;s:5:"asset";a:5:{s:6:"_class";s:5:"asset";s:2:"id";i:2670950;s:10:"asset_type";s:5:"Video";s:5:"title";s:12:"section2.mov";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-02-09T19:27:44Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:104;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:0;}i:12;a:7:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"chapter";s:2:"id";i:596394;s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-01-19T11:52:45Z";s:10:"sort_order";i:103;s:5:"title";s:28:"Creating pixel art - Shading";s:11:"description";s:96:"Once you've mastered the creationg of pixelated line art, its time to fill that in with shading!";s:12:"is_published";b:1;}i:13;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:2384812;s:5:"title";s:25:"Shading in the real world";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-02-09T18:07:30Z";s:11:"description";s:140:"

Before we can shade in pixel art, we should look at some real life examples, and see how light affects different surfaces

";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:25:"shading-in-the-real-world";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"transcript";N;s:15:"is_downloadable";b:0;s:7:"is_free";b:0;s:5:"asset";a:5:{s:6:"_class";s:5:"asset";s:2:"id";i:2670534;s:10:"asset_type";s:5:"Video";s:5:"title";s:22:"ShadinginRealWorld.mov";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-02-09T18:21:15Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:102;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:0;}i:14;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:2260114;s:5:"title";s:27:"Shading a sphere and a cube";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-01-19T11:53:31Z";s:11:"description";s:271:"

In Pixel Art, everything is 2D. But how can we make objects look three-dimensional? We have to use shading. When we shade an object, we give it a sense of volume. there are a few rules to this. This lecture explains them by using primitive solids as an example.

";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:27:"shading-a-sphere-and-a-cube";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"transcript";N;s:15:"is_downloadable";b:0;s:7:"is_free";b:0;s:5:"asset";a:5:{s:6:"_class";s:5:"asset";s:2:"id";i:2531768;s:10:"asset_type";s:5:"Video";s:5:"title";s:24:"05.ShadingSphereCube.avi";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-01-19T13:35:06Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:101;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:0;}i:15;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:2260120;s:5:"title";s:33:"Shading a pyramid and a cylinder.";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-01-19T11:54:10Z";s:11:"description";s:228:"

After learning the most simple solids (Sphere and Cube) its time to have a go at another couple of simple volumes: A pyramid and a cylinder. These two new volumes follow the same rules, but have unique characteristics.

";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:32:"shading-a-pyramid-and-a-cylinder";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"transcript";N;s:15:"is_downloadable";b:0;s:7:"is_free";b:0;s:5:"asset";a:5:{s:6:"_class";s:5:"asset";s:2:"id";i:2531740;s:10:"asset_type";s:5:"Video";s:5:"title";s:29:"06.ShadingCylinderPyramid.avi";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-01-19T13:29:50Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:100;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:0;}i:16;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:2260124;s:5:"title";s:34:"Creating an apple sprite - Shading";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-01-19T11:54:33Z";s:11:"description";s:192:"

With the skill of shading, we now have the power to move into a three-dimensional object: An Apple. We discuss the apple's unique shape, and how it affects the shading.

";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:32:"creating-an-apple-sprite-shading";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"transcript";N;s:15:"is_downloadable";b:0;s:7:"is_free";b:1;s:5:"asset";a:5:{s:6:"_class";s:5:"asset";s:2:"id";i:2531778;s:10:"asset_type";s:5:"Video";s:5:"title";s:13:"07.Apple1.avi";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-01-19T13:36:49Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:99;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:1;}i:17;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:2260128;s:5:"title";s:35:"Creating an apple sprite - Outlines";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-01-19T11:54:42Z";s:11:"description";s:145:"

Outlines are one of the best ways to make objects stand out from the background. In this lecture we give a try to 3 types or outlining.

";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:33:"creating-an-apple-sprite-outlines";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"transcript";N;s:15:"is_downloadable";b:0;s:7:"is_free";b:0;s:5:"asset";a:5:{s:6:"_class";s:5:"asset";s:2:"id";i:2531754;s:10:"asset_type";s:5:"Video";s:5:"title";s:13:"08.Apple2.avi";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-01-19T13:31:54Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:98;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:0;}i:18;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:2260132;s:5:"title";s:34:"Creating an apple sprite - Texture";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-01-19T11:54:58Z";s:11:"description";s:235:"

While still using the colors from the shading, we can add a layer of texture buy changing how we shade the volume. If instead of smooth shapes we take the care to add some variation to our transitions, we can suggest texture.

";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:32:"creating-an-apple-sprite-texture";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"transcript";N;s:15:"is_downloadable";b:0;s:7:"is_free";b:0;s:5:"asset";a:5:{s:6:"_class";s:5:"asset";s:2:"id";i:2531798;s:10:"asset_type";s:5:"Video";s:5:"title";s:13:"09.Apple3.avi";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-01-19T13:42:04Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:97;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:0;}i:19;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:2260136;s:5:"title";s:40:"Creating an apple sprite - Bounced Light";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-01-19T11:55:12Z";s:11:"description";s:265:"

Shading gives and object volume, and an outline makes it stand out. But how do we make and object seem to belong in a scene? We need to light it with additional light. In this lecture I should the use of bounced light, so help place an object on the scene

";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:38:"creating-an-apple-sprite-bounced-light";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"transcript";N;s:15:"is_downloadable";b:0;s:7:"is_free";b:0;s:5:"asset";a:5:{s:6:"_class";s:5:"asset";s:2:"id";i:2531804;s:10:"asset_type";s:5:"Video";s:5:"title";s:13:"10.Apple4.avi";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-01-19T13:43:43Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:96;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:0;}i:20;a:14:{s:6:"_class";s:4:"quiz";s:2:"id";i:115700;s:5:"title";s:7:"Shading";s:4:"type";s:11:"simple-quiz";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-02-20T16:16:47Z";s:11:"description";s:0:"";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:0:"";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"sort_order";i:95;s:12:"object_index";i:2;s:8:"is_draft";b:0;s:7:"version";i:1;s:8:"duration";N;s:12:"pass_percent";N;}i:21;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:2260148;s:5:"title";s:57:"Revisiting the Sword sprite - Adding shading and outlines";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-01-19T11:57:16Z";s:11:"description";s:182:"

With all that we learned about shading, we can now go back into our sword sprite and add even more detail what what we had previously, turning it into a fully shaded sword.

";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:55:"revisiting-the-sword-sprite-adding-shading-and-outlines";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"transcript";N;s:15:"is_downloadable";b:0;s:7:"is_free";b:0;s:5:"asset";a:5:{s:6:"_class";s:5:"asset";s:2:"id";i:2531816;s:10:"asset_type";s:5:"Video";s:5:"title";s:19:"11.SwordSprite2.avi";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-01-19T13:49:38Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:94;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:0;}i:22;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:2494826;s:5:"title";s:28:"EXERCISE - Shading a chalice";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-02-27T10:43:49Z";s:11:"description";s:110:"

Please use the file attached and shade it to make it look like a gold chalice with encrusted rubies.

Tiles are by far the most used technique for filling the screen with a world. From Platformers to RPGs, tiles have always been widely used . This lecture serves as an introduction to the concept behind tiles.

With the concept sinking in, we can now go and make out base tile. This will be our main orientation, as it will provide size, style, color palette, volume and camera perspective.

";s:13:"title_cleaned";s:22:"creating-the-base-tile";s:12:"is_published";b:1;s:10:"transcript";N;s:15:"is_downloadable";b:0;s:7:"is_free";b:0;s:5:"asset";a:5:{s:6:"_class";s:5:"asset";s:2:"id";i:2570290;s:10:"asset_type";s:5:"Video";s:5:"title";s:26:"13.CreatingTheBaseTile.avi";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-01-25T22:08:57Z";}s:10:"sort_order";i:78;s:16:"can_be_previewed";b:0;}i:37;a:13:{s:6:"_class";s:7:"lecture";s:2:"id";i:2261710;s:5:"title";s:49:"Creating a simple background and adjusting colors";s:7:"created";s:20:"2015-01-19T16:09:40Z";s:11:"description";s:258:"

With a bunch of things established, we can move a little more forward with the mockup, by adding a background. In this lecture I show a really quick and simple way to create a background scene that will serve as a backdrop for the mockup.

The game world will be made with all these tiles, so it would be nice to have some variation. Taking some of the lessons learned in previous lectures we add variation and depth to out mockup by adding variation in the tiles
